awd_titl_txt: DCL: GOLD-EN EAGER: CUltivating socially Responsible ATmospheric scientists through Education, Leadership, and Action (CURATE)
awd_abstract_narration:
A challenge of note in STEM is that diversity, equity and inclusion is often siloed from many aspects of the scientific process and portions of the atmospheric science scientific community. New approaches and entry points at higher levels of engagement are needed to foster “a diverse community of researchers, scholars, and practitioners” in the geosciences. To this end, the PIs will develop a novel hybrid (face-to-face and online components) atmospheric science course designed to break down traditional barriers for entry into diversity, equity and inclusion engagement by graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. The course will provide the structure and resources to help participants emerge as new “diversity leaders,” better prepared to address issues of participation, representation and inclusion challenges that are uniquely faced in the geosciences.   

The PIs plan to bridge DEI gaps by developing a new atmospheric science course, for inclusion in the graduate curriculum, designed to break down traditional barriers for entry into DEI engagement by graduate students. The course will provide the structure and resources to help participants emerge as new “diversity leaders,” better prepared to address issues of participation, representation and inclusion challenges that are uniquely faced in the geosciences. This course will provide an action-oriented mechanism and model to train, educate, and empower a growing cohort of diversity leaders. Specific course and related activity objectives include training on how to 1) identify social identity and how it shapes scientific thought and practice, 2) evaluate and explain the impacts of science and technology on marginalized groups, 3)identify and respond to manifestations of implicit and explicit bias in STEM, 4) recognize social justice issues in the geoscience community and beyond with a focus on designing and implementing interventions and 5) act as advocates and allies for people with different life-experiences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project, titled "Cultivating Socially Responsible Atmospheric Scientists through Education, Leadership, and Action (CURATE), focused on developing and implementing a graduate course increasing students awareness and exposure to address broadening participation issues in the geosciences.

Intellectual Merit:

 

The project's intellectual merit lies in its innovative approach to addressing the lack of diversity in geosciences. By creating a specialized graduate course, "ATS 660: Social Responsibility in Atmospheric Science," the project introduced a new educational framework. This course, offered multiple times, delved into topics like social identity, bias in STEM, and inclusive practices. The course's evolution, from an experimental phase to a regular offering, demonstrates a rigorous refinement process and excitement about the course. The use of diverse teaching methods, including guest lectures from experts and interactive activities like the Workshop Activity for Gender Equity Simulation (WAGES), enriched the learning experience. The development of mini online modules further expanded the reach of these educational materials. Community service action projects have really strengthened and had direct impact on aspects of how we conduct and engage in science for our department and the community.

 

Broader Impacts:

 

The project's broader impacts are significant. It has trained 41 graduate students to identify and address DEI issues in STEM, fostering a new generation of "diversity champions." These students, from various scientific backgrounds, have engaged in community action service-learning projects, addressing real-world issues like improving public transportation for international students and increasing science outreach in local schools. The project also contributed to the development of resources like "Datasheets for Earth Science Datasets," which was accepted for publication.

The project team disseminated their findings through presentations at national meetings and publications in the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society, reaching a wider audience and influencing other institutions to adopt similar DEI initiatives. The project's efforts to make the developed course a requirement for PhD students at CSU and to create additional courses on Climate Justice will have a lasting impact on the department and the field of atmospheric science. By addressing the lack of diversity in geosciences, the project contributes to creating a more inclusive and equitable scientific community, which ultimately benefits society by fostering innovation and diverse perspectives in addressing critical issues like climate change.

Summary of Award Outcomes:

The CURATE project successfully developed and implemented the "ATS 660" graduate course, focusing on broadening participation issues in atmospheric science. The course was refined over several iterations and reached a diverse group of graduate students. Online modules were created to extend the course's impact, and these modules were integrated into other courses across the campus. The project also fostered community engagement through student-led service projects and contributed to scholarly discourse through publications and presentations. The long-term goal of making social responsibility a course a requirement for all PhD students in the department is underway. Overall, the project has significantly contributed to raising awareness and promoting action towards diversity, equity, and inclusion in the field of atmospheric science and beyond.
